intro: Clarkia pulchella var. striata, commonly known as the striped Clarkia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Onagraceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and grasslands. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are often reddish in color. The varietal name "striata" refers to the distinct, alternating stripes on its petals, which add to its ornamental appeal.
